For example, the position of the State on this question is that if simply the run were destroyed, the natural run were entirely destroyed and replaced by a hatchery run, then basically there is no more treaty entitlement to that fish.
Secondly, on the sovereign-immunity question, the Attorney General has understated the issue substantially.

Basically on the sovereign-immunity issue, if this Court affirms, you are opening up litigation against a tribe to allocate and apportion its natural resources in State Courts throughout the State of Washington.
The Congress has never permitted such a lawsuit, and I submit that if there is an affirmance on that sovereign-immunity proposition, the effects would be devastating.
But would that not be limited to -- even if we take your assumption, limited to cases where there is an artificial input or artificial --
Absolutely not.
Again in response to Mr. Justice Whiteâ€™s question, I believe, the sovereign-immunity defense would apply regardless of the nature of the claim.
They are suing the Tribe, and they have secured orders against the Tribe.
The so-called petty orders include directives to the Tribal Council of the close fisheries under threat of contempt.
Well, what is allocation now to the Puyallup Indians?
The allocation issue is as follows: basically, there is an off-reservation, the Bolt decision indicates a 50/50 allocation question.
The court below allocated on a 45/55 basis; for our purposes, that is insignificant.
There is a further question whether the hatchery fish are excluded.

Presently, under Federal Court order pending adjudication of this entire question in Phase II of United States against Washington, the State is enjoined from excluding hatchery fish from its regulatory activity with regard to all runs, including the Puyallup River.

Now, that meant, again in response to another question, that there indeed is a possibility of Federal/State injunctions, and this Court has looked with a lack of encouragement to that activity, and we have had alternatives and occasionally have gone before the Federal Court to seek injunctive relief.
But on this question, on the question of State power to control on-reservation, we have come up through direct appeals.
Mr. Rodgers, at what point in the litigation did you first assert sovereign immunity as a defense?
Sovereign immunity, Your Honor, has been asserted in this litigation ever since the case began.
It was rejected in Puyallup I on the premise that we were dealing with an action against individuals off-reservation.
That premise has now dissipated.
It has been urged throughout here and was decided against us on the merits by the Washington State Supreme Court.
Of course, that court thought it was doing no more than obeying the order on remand of this Court in Puyallup II.
That is correct, Your Honor.

So instead of the wide precedent that you have indicated that affirmance here might mean, really, this is just limited to the Washington Supreme Courtâ€™s carrying out what this Court told it to do on remand of this particular and precise case, isnâ€™t it?
But to do that, Your Honor, as the concurring opinion below indicates, you have to read Puyallup II as contradicting 150 years of Indian law.
Yes.
And we believe that you cannot do that.
In conclusion of what --
Mr. Rodgers, let me ask you one more question.

I take it if you are right and this sovereign immunity should have been recognized far earlier than now that both of our decisions in Puyallup I and Puyallup II are wiped out, because if the Supreme Court of Washington had no jurisdiction, we surely had no jurisdiction.
No, Your Honor, because those cases based upon the premises established -- and indeed, they were facts -- and those cases were off-reservation cases involving individual Indians --
Same case as this case.
It is the same, same litigation.
How and where do the facts --
Except the reservation now exists, and the orders that initially run against individuals now run against the Tribe.
The Tribal Council, the tribal governing body, its legislative body, has been ordered to enact closures, to enforce closures.
The case has been transformed into an off-reservation individual case into an on-reservation suit against the Tribe itself.
And I would submit in conclusion that the history of this litigation has been determined by one overriding factor, and that is to restrict the Indian fishery.

We have had in this case argued at various times that the tribe is defunct, that the treaty is a worthless scrap of paper, that the reservation does not exist, but that if it does there is power to control as if it did not.
We urge the Court to reverse.
We urge the Court to go further and to dismiss on the ground, we fear, that the slightest ambiguity in its disposition will result in additional litigation.
Thank you.
Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
